title: I am being sued, cannot pay the $12.000 they want, I do not make a lot of money.
question: I am being sued by a collection agency contracted by bank of america, they are taking me to court. I do not make that much money will they look at my pay stubs to see how much I make and lower the amount I owe ? and make low payments. I am worried that if I can't pay what they want they will garnish my check from my jobs. I can barley pay my bills now. can you help me with a peace of mind?
answers:
Remember, BK is more than checking boxes on forms you find online. Find/consult/hire a lawyer using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some of us offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it.

Because the bankruptcy process can be handled entirely by phone, email and fax, there is no need to personally visit the lawyer’s office unless you want to. Don’t be limited by the location of the BK lawyers you select.

Do you have other debts? Experience tells me that when you are confronting financial difficulties, there often is more than one past due obligation.

The reason I ask is that if you have at least $12,000 of debt that is beyond your ability to pay without compromising your ability to meet your basic needs, step one may be to consult with a qualified bankruptcy attorney. In the state civil court, the outcome is merely a judgment of whether the debt is owed or not. If you do not dispute that the debt is owing, the creditor is entitled to a judgment determining the amount of the debt. The only thing a civil judge in state court can do for you is to determine if the creditor should be allowed to garnish up to 25% of your paycheck, or perhaps a lower percentage based upon your claim of exemption. Similarly, the court can protect your exempt assets if you file the proper papers, but it cannot make the debt go away.

That requires a bankruptcy discharge. Before you spend money with an attorney trying to prove you don't owe a debt, when you do, you should first explore the bankruptcy option, which for less money and costs may result in wiping the slate clean and giving you a fresh start.

The court will not take your income into account. The creditor can garnish your wages after obtaining a judgment and writ of execution, however, the process takes some time. I would recommend speaking to some bankruptcy attorneys to see if bankruptcy is a good option for you, especially if you have other debt. Bankruptcy can put an end to the lawsuit and get rid of the debt you owe, giving you a fresh new start.

first and foremost you need to talk to a bankruptcy attorney in your area to see if bankruptcy is a viable option for you. Go on AVVO to find one or two in your area that offers free consults. Then take advantage of it.

If you have other debts in addition to the one that resulted in a lawsuit, you may want to file a bankruptcy case. If you do not file a bankruptcy case, you will need to talk to a debt collection defense attorney. If you cannot afford to hire a private attorney, contact a legal aid office in your area that handles consumer debt cases.
I would answer the complaint to avoid having a default judgment entered against you. I would ask for a consultation from an attorney. which law firm is suing you?

First, demand (in writing) that they verify the debt.

No, the court won’t take your income into account.

You need a consultation with a lawyer, and you can probably get it for free.

You should go see a bankruptcy lawyer, or two and discuss your financial situation. Take all the paperwork. Not necessarily because you should file bankruptcy, but because BK lawyers are trained to know what if any are the options for you, and most will provide a free consultation and tell you exactly what you need to know.
